awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Data-Driven Model Reduction for Optimal Control of Large-Scale Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Dynamical systems are a principal tool in the modeling, prediction, and control of physical phenomena ranging from heat dissipation in complex microelectronic devices,  to vibration suppression in large wind turbines, to flow simulation. Optimal control of dynamical systems plays an important role in the many science and engineering applications where one wants to generate inputs to improve the performance of a system. However, ever-increasing need to include more detail at the modeling stage inevitably leads to larger-scale, more complex dynamical systems. Many of these large-scale systems are obtained from spatial discretizations of time-dependent coupled systems of partial differential equations. The simulation of such complex dynamical systems creates huge demands on computational resources and such high fidelity simulations may become unmanageable when the system needs to be queried at many different inputs. This project develops and applies a new class of model reduction methods for the efficient simulation and optimal control of dynamical systems. The model reduction approaches developed in this project approximate large, complex models of time-dependent processes using smaller, computationally efficient models that are nonetheless capable of representing accurately the outputs of the original process under a variety of operating conditions. Thus the new model reduction methods allow simulation and control of systems that would otherwise not be practical with high fidelity computational models.

The new model reduction methods developed in this project are data-driven. Unlike existing methods, in many cases, the new methods allow the generation of efficient reduced order computational models directly from (experimental) data and do not require access to high fidelity computational simulations. Overall, this new approach offers several advancements. First, it generates a reduced order model of the original nonlinear dynamical system that is valid for all inputs. Second, the new approach is data-driven and avoids the use of projections. This means less detailed access to the components of the original system are needed, which makes the new method particularly attractive when details of system simulation is inaccessible. This project will develop mathematical algorithms for the creation of such data-driven reduced order models and provide theoretical analyses of their performance. In addition, this project integrates the new model reduction approach into the solution of optimal control problems. For this integration, crucial additional input-output relations will be identified and the reduced order model generation will be augmented to ensure that these additional input-output relations are well approximated. This new approach will be applied to simulation and control of important biological phenomena and of fluid flows.

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed extensions of the recently so-called Loewner framework (LF) for data-driven system identification and model reduction of important classes of dynamical systems, it has provided analyses to provide theoretical performance guarantees of these extensions, and it has demonstrated the performance of developed tools to model systems arising in computational neuroscience, fluid dynamics, and fuel cells.


The LF fuses data with knowledge of fundamental mathematical structures of the underlying system to identify a reduced order models of the system that matches the systems input-to-output behavior. In contrast to purely data-driven machine learning (ML) techniques, the LF also incorporates fundamental mathematical structures of the underlying system. In contrast to snapshot-based methods, such as Proper Orthogonal Decomposition (POD) or Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD), that also incorporate some fundamental mathematical structures, the LF only requires input-to-output data but does not need access to state-space information. Moreover, in the linear time-invariant (LTI) case, if enough data is available, the Loewner model is accurate for all inputs as it identifies system invariant quantities of the underlying dynamical system. This result can be extended under suitable assumptions to the quadratic bilinear case. In contrast, snapshot-based methods are input-dependent and behave accurately only for inputs that are close to those used in the training stage.


In this project, the LF has been extended to identify nonlinear block-oriented Hammerstein models. Hammerstein models appear in some important control engineering applications where the actuator (control input) enters a static nonlinear block and after the processed signal is used as an input to a LTI system. The developed method based on the LF has been successful in identifying the hidden Hammerstein model from input-output measurements. These results also indicate the potential of generalizations of the LF to other types of block-oriented systems such as Wiener models or linear systems with quadratic outputs.


This project has also provided important extensions of the LF so that it can now be applied to compute reduced order models (ROMs) of many types of complex and nonlinear systems, including quadratic-bilinear systems and switched systems, and quadratic-bilinear differential algebraic systems. Many nonlinear systems are already in this form or they can be transformed into such systems via so-called lifting (introduction of auxiliary variables and dynamic equations). Therefore these system classes represent a large, important classes of nonlinear systems. Examples include the Chafee-Infante, FitzHugh-Nagumo, Burgers', Oseen, Stokes and Navier-Stokes equations. 


Another data-driven method that has recently emerged is the so-called operator inference framework (OpInf). This approach uses time-domain state measurements (snapshots of the state variable) and knowledge of the polynomial structure of the underlying model to generate a polynomial projection-based ROM. This is done by using least-squares type methods to determine projected matrices arising in the polynomial ROM from data. However, the OpInf framework requires measurements of the whole state variable, whereas the LF requires only input-output measurements (transfer function measurements of higher-order generalized transfer functions). We have developed hybrids of the OpInf and the LF. As in the LF, this hybrid approach enforces approximation of the input-to-output map, but used an OpInf to determine bilinear or purely quadratic ROMs from transfer function. A more involved extension that accounts for fitting additional bilinear or trilinear operators is currently being pursued. Finally, we also explored the discrete-time setup is explored by identifying bilinear models from time-domain series (obtained by sampling the control input and the observed output).


As mentioned earlier, the developed extensions of the LF were successfully applied to applications. One application aims at improving durability of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFC), which is crucial for their commercialization. It was demonstrated that the analyzes of the input-output data of PEMFCs using the LF facilitates the interpretation of the related frequency domain spectra and significantly reduces the time needed for performing the frequency response experiments. In particular, using transfer functions resulting from data, it was possible to calculate the characteristic frequencies (DCF), which enable the identification of the polarization losses related to all the phenomena underlying the EIS spectra. Continuous monitoring of these losses provides information on the degradation of specific components of the operating PEMFC and can form the basis for an onboard diagnostic tool. Additionally, incorporating the LF into the analysis of cFRA data reduces the time to conduct experiments. Hence the application of this methodology as an online diagnostic tool in mobile applications becomes feasible. 


While the developed extensions of the LF have substantially expanded the applicability and theoretical understanding of this method, this project has also revealed avenues of future research that would increase applicability of the LF. These include a complete understanding of the interaction between Volterra series truncation and approximation of resulting transfer function components by the ROM, more detailed analyses/enforcement of ROM stability properties, and better understanding of the impact of different lifting procedures on the resulting ROM construction.
